title: Why Satan is NOT in the Old Testament [Job 1-3]

body: So when did it change for the New Testament?
body_html: So when did it change for the New Testament?

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: Just more word mangling as usual. Satan and devil are both just transliterations of "accuser" in the sense of a court or legal prosecution. But no one likes that because it shows that this is the enemy's trait and we like to be judgemental and vengeful.
body_html: Just more word mangling as usual. Satan and devil are both just transliterations of "accuser" in the sense of a court or legal prosecution. But no one likes that because it shows that this is the enemy's trait and we like to be judgemental and vengeful.

body:
Not having a go at you, but just so I'm clear: You're saying you think Satan in the book of Job IS the same chief overlord of evil in the New Testament?
If so I'd have to disagree.
body_html: Not having a go at you, but just so I'm clear: You're saying you think Satan in the book of Job IS the same chief overlord of evil in the New Testament? If so I'd have to disagree.

body: Sure, that's what the video is about. How in the original Hebrew it's more likely a heavenly servant who works for God than one of his enemies.
